elements.content: Several divalent copper coordination polymers containing both 5-sulfoisophthalate (sip) and bis(pyridyl)piperazine type co-ligands have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Across this series, the nature of the neutral co-ligands plays a crucial structure-directing role. Bis(3-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (3-bpmp) and its isomer bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (4-bpmp) afforded layered phases with different topologies. {[Cu(sip)(H3-bpmp)(H2O)]·3H2O} n (1) and {[Cu(sip)(H4-bpmp)(H2O)]·4H2O} n (2) both possess (4,4) grid topologies, although the latter exhibits mutually inclined 2D + 2D → 3D interpenetration. {[Cu(sip)(H4-bpmp)]·7.5H2O} n (3), which forms concomitantly with 2, has an uncommon (3,6) triangular grid layer based on {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers. A lower temperature pseudopolymorph, {[Cu6(sip)6(H24-bpmp)3(H2O)20]·4H2O} n (4), is an oligomeric molecular species. Employing bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) generated {[Cu4(sip)2(OH)2(H2O)3(4-bpfp)]·H2O} n (5), which manifests {Cu4(OH)2} “butterfly” clusters linked into a unique three-dimensional (3-D) 3,3,8-connected trinodal lattice with (3.42)(426)(3244536977829) topology. The copper clusters in 3 and 5 exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: Divalent copper coordination polymers containing 5-sulfoisophthalate (sip) and neutral co-ligands have been synthesized and characterized. {[Cu(sip)(H4-bpmp)]·7.5H2O} n (3, 4-bpmp = bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) has a (3,6) triangular grid layer based on dinuclear units. {[Cu4(sip)2(OH)2(H2O)3(4-bpfp)]·H2O} n (5, 4-bpfp = bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine) has tetrameric clusters linked into a unique 3,3,8-connected trinodal lattice. The copper clusters in 3 and 5 exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling.

The copper clusters in 3 and 5 exhibit antiferromagnetic coupling.

elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of divalent metal coordination polymers remain under intensive investigation, with efforts geared toward the design of materials tailored to industrially relevant hydrogen storage, molecular separation, ion exchange, catalysis, and nonlinear optical applications. Dicarboxylate ligands are certainly the most commonly employed linkers in the construction of these materials, providing structural rigidity to the resulting phases, promoting open network topologies, and preventing inclusion of pore-clogging anionic species in most cases. The geometric orientation of carboxylate donors, divalent metal coordination preferences, and carboxylate binding or bridging modes provide a plethora of diverse structural topologies. Additionally, carboxylate bridges can instill spin communication and temperature- and field-dependent magnetic properties in these phases, which depend heavily on the overlap mechanisms for the magnetic orbitals on neighboring paramagnetic metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis and characterization of divalent metal coordination polymers remain under intensive investigation, with efforts geared toward the design of materials tailored to industrially relevant hydrogen storage, molecular separation, ion exchange, catalysis, and nonlinear optical applications. Dicarboxylate ligands are certainly the most commonly employed linkers in the construction of these materials, providing structural rigidity to the resulting phases, promoting open network topologies, and preventing inclusion of pore-clogging anionic species in most cases. The geometric orientation of carboxylate donors, divalent metal coordination preferences, and carboxylate binding or bridging modes provide a plethora of diverse structural topologies. Additionally, carboxylate bridges can instill spin communication and temperature- and field-dependent magnetic properties in these phases, which depend heavily on the overlap mechanisms for the magnetic orbitals on neighboring paramagnetic metal ions.

elements.content: Multicarboxylate ligands such as 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate or 1,2,4-benzenetricarboxylate have demonstrated significant utility in the construction of gas-absorbing microporous or magnetically active coordination polymer phases, many with intriguing structural topologies. In contrast, the trianionic 5-sulfoisophthalate (sip) ligand (Scheme ) has been less well studied in coordination polymer systems. Here, the sulfonate moiety can act as either a weakly binding group or a negatively charged unligated pendant group; in either case it can exert an important structure-directing role. Stoichiometric ratio has proven critical in defining the structural topologies of divalent metal/sip extended phases. In compounds where a 1:1 divalent metal/sip stoichiometric ratio is observed, charge balance must be provided by interstitial alkaline earth metal or ammonium cations (as in {[Ca(H2O)3Cu2(H2O)6(sip)2]·2H2O} n and {[Cu(sip)(H2O)4](H2en)0.5} n ), or protonation of pyridyl ligands (as in {[Cd(sip)(H4,4′-bpy)(H2O)]·2H2O} n , 4,4′-bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine), or in protonation of the sulfonate group (as in [{Cu(H2O)2(Hsip)}·2H2O·(piperazine)1/2] n ). Single protonation of any dipyridyl ligands tends to induce simple one-dimensional (1-D) chains bridged only by sip ligands, because of the resulting loss of nitrogen lone pair ligating ability. Inclusion of cationic interstitial species or ligand protonation is avoided in compounds with a 3:2 divalent metal/sip ratio such as {[Cu1.5(sip)(py)5](py)(H2O)6.76} n (py = pyridine) and [Cu3(sip)2(H2O)14], which adopt (6,3) honeycomb layer and 0-D molecular topologies, respectively. In other complexes, a cationic 2:1 divalent metal/sip ratio is balanced by triply bridging hydroxide ions within tetranuclear copper clusters, as seen in [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2(2,2′-bipyridine)2(H2O)2] n and {[Cu4(OH)2(sip)2(H2O)2]·4H2O} n . These coordination polymers adopt uncommon three-dimensional (3-D) rutile ((4.62)2(4261083) topology) and 3-D fluorite variant ((456)2(41161483) topology) networks, respectively.

elements.clean_text: 1  Ligands Used in This Study

elements.content: Recently, our group has employed bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (4-bpmp) and bis(3-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (3-bpmp) ligands as long-spanning tethering ligands for the construction of coordination polymers with novel topologies (Scheme ). At times the central piperazinyl rings can become protonated under the synthetic conditions, with concomitant anion inclusion at times, as seen in the self-penetrated 2-D coordination polymer {[Zn3(tricarballylate)2(4-bpmp)(H-4-bpmp)2](ClO4)2·5H2O} n and 3-D doubly interpenetrated 4,8-connected binodal network phase {[Zn5(5-nitroisophthalate)6(H-4-bpmp)2(4-bpmp)]·2H2O} n . As a result we sought to probe whether protonated 3-bpmp or 4-bpmp ligands could provide the required charge balance for successful generation of higher dimensionality copper/sip coordination polymers with a 1:1 stoichiometric ratio in contrast to the 1-D chains previously reported. In order to avoid potential piperazinyl ring protonation, we have also employed the bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) ligand, whose amide linkages substantially reduce lone pair character at the piperazinyl nitrogen atoms, and whose formyl groups could provide an additional site for ligation or hydrogen-bonding acceptance. The coordination polymer chemistry of 4-bpfp remains underdeveloped. Herein we report the synthesis and structure of a series of topologically diverse divalent copper 5-sulfoisophthalate complexes containing these piperazinyl-containing dipyridyl ligands: {[Cu(sip)(H3-bpmp)(H2O)]·3H2O} n (1), {[Cu(sip)(H4-bpmp)(H2O)]·4H2O} n (2), {[Cu(sip)(H4-bpmp)]·7.5H2O} n (3), {[Cu6(sip)6(H24-bpmp)3(H2O)20]·4H2O} n (4), and {[Cu4(sip)2(OH)2(H2O)3(4-bpfp)]·H2O} n (5). Magnetic superexchange within cluster units evident in 3 and 5 was also probed.

elements.content: Copper salts were purchased from Aldrich. Sodium 5-sulfoisophthalic acid was purchased from TCI America. Bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) and bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine isomers (4-bpmp and 3-bpmp) were prepared using published procedures. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility data for 3 and 5 (2 to 300 K) were collected on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.1 T. After each temperature change, the sample was kept at the new temperature for 5 min before magnetization measurements to ensure thermal equilibrium. The susceptibility data were corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal’s constants and for the diamagnetism of the sample holder.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

Copper salts were purchased from Aldrich. Sodium 5-sulfoisophthalic acid was purchased from TCI America. Bis(4-pyridylformyl)piperazine (4-bpfp) and bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine isomers (4-bpmp and 3-bpmp) were prepared using published procedures. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility data for 3 and 5 (2 to 300 K) were collected on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.1 T. After each temperature change, the sample was kept at the new temperature for 5 min before magnetization measurements to ensure thermal equilibrium. The susceptibility data were corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal's constants and for the diamagnetism of the sample holder.

elements.content: Copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (71.5 mg, 0.296 mmol), 3-bpmp (79.3 mg, 0.296 mmol), and sodium 5-sulfoisophthalic acid (78.8 mg, 0.296 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Blue blocks of 1 (130 mg, 0.100 mmol, 68% yield based on Cu) were isolated after washing with distilled water, acetone, and drying in air. Anal. Calc. for C48H64Cu2N8O22S2 1: C, 44.47; H, 4.98; N, 8.64% Found: C, 44.05; H, 4.69; N, 8.60%. elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction was performed for 1−5 using a Bruker-AXS ApexII CCD instrument at 173 K. Reflection data were acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Crystals of 1 were both nonmerohedrally twinned. The twin law was determined using CELLNOW. Only the reflections from the major twin component was used in structure refinement. Higher than expected R1 and wR2 statistics for 1 are attributed to both twinning and small crystal size. A slight amount of racemic twinning was observed for the crystal of 2, with a Flack parameter of 0.15(2). The hydrogen atoms bound to any piperazinyl nitrogen atoms and the unligated or ligated water molecules were found via Fourier difference maps where possible, and then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. Relevant crystallographic data for 1−5 are listed in Table . Topological analyses were carried out using TOPOS software.

X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction was performed for 1-5 using a Bruker-AXS ApexII CCD instrument at 173 K. Reflection data were acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. Crystals of 1 were both nonmerohedrally twinned. The twin law was determined using CELLNOW. Only the reflections from the major twin component was used in structure refinement. Higher than expected R1 and wR2 statistics for 1 are attributed to both twinning and small crystal size. A slight amount of racemic twinning was observed for the crystal of 2, with a Flack parameter of 0.15(2). The hydrogen atoms bound to any piperazinyl nitrogen atoms and the unligated or ligated water molecules were found via Fourier difference maps where possible, and then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. Relevant crystallographic data for 1-5 are listed in Table . Topological analyses were carried out using TOPOS software.

Compounds 1−5 were prepared as crystalline products by hydrothermal reaction of copper nitrate and sodium 5-sulfoisophthalic acid with the requisite dipyridyl ligand. Compound 2 was obtained as a minor product in the synthesis of 3, while 4 was obtained cleanly at a lower temperature. The infrared spectra of 1−5 were consistent with their structural characteristics as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Weak and medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600 cm−1 to ∼1200 cm−1 can be ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of nitrogen-base ligands. Puckering modes of the aromatic rings are evident in the region between 820 cm−1 and 600 cm−1. Asymmetric and symmetric C−O stretching modes of the carboxylate groups of fully deprotonated sip ligands correspond to the strong, broadened features at 1608 cm−1 and 1436 cm−1 (for 1), 1621 cm−1 and 1430 cm−1 (for 2), 1614 cm−1 and 1445 cm−1 (for 3), 1605 cm−1 and 1428 cm−1 (for 4), or 1557 cm−1 and 1440 cm−1 (for 5). Broad yet weak bands in the region of ∼3400 cm−1 to ∼3200 cm−1 represent N−H stretching modes within the protonated bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands (1−3) and O−H bonds within ligated and/or unbound water molecules in all cases. The broadness of these higher energy spectral features is caused by the hydrogen bonding present in all cases (see below). The presence of the sulfonate groups within 1−5 is corroborated by strong S−O stretching bands at ∼1350 cm−1 in all cases.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Spectral Characterization

Compounds 1-5 were prepared as crystalline products by hydrothermal reaction of copper nitrate and sodium 5-sulfoisophthalic acid with the requisite dipyridyl ligand. Compound 2 was obtained as a minor product in the synthesis of 3, while 4 was obtained cleanly at a lower temperature. The infrared spectra of 1-5 were consistent with their structural characteristics as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Weak and medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600 cm-1 to ~1200 cm-1 can be ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of nitrogen-base ligands. Puckering modes of the aromatic rings are evident in the region between 820 cm-1 and 600 cm-1. Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the carboxylate groups of fully deprotonated sip ligands correspond to the strong, broadened features at 1608 cm-1 and 1436 cm-1 (for 1), 1621 cm-1 and 1430 cm-1 (for 2), 1614 cm-1 and 1445 cm-1 (for 3), 1605 cm-1 and 1428 cm-1 (for 4), or 1557 cm-1 and 1440 cm-1 (for 5). Broad yet weak bands in the region of ~3400 cm-1 to ~3200 cm-1 represent N-H stretching modes within the protonated bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands (1-3) and O-H bonds within ligated and/or unbound water molecules in all cases. The broadness of these higher energy spectral features is caused by the hydrogen bonding present in all cases (see below). The presence of the sulfonate groups within 1-5 is corroborated by strong S-O stretching bands at ~1350 cm-1 in all cases.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains two crystallographically distinct divalent copper ions (Cu1, Cu2), two sip ligands, two bound water molecules, two 3-bpmp molecules protonated at one of their respective piperazinyl nitrogen atoms, and six total water molecules of crystallization. Each of the copper ions has a distorted {CuN2O3} square pyramidal coordination environment (), with trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two H-3-bpmp ligands and trans sip carboxylate oxygen atom donors. Deviations from idealized square pyramidal geometry are different at Cu1 and Cu2, with Addison τ trigonality factors equal to 0.173 and 0.127, respectively. The long bond length apical positions at all copper ions are taken up by aqua ligands. Pertinent bond lengths and angles about copper are consistent with the coordination environment and d 9 Jahn−Teller active electronic configuration and are given in .

The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains two crystallographically distinct divalent copper ions (Cu1, Cu2), two sip ligands, two bound water molecules, two 3-bpmp molecules protonated at one of their respective piperazinyl nitrogen atoms, and six total water molecules of crystallization. Each of the copper ions has a distorted {CuN2O3} square pyramidal coordination environment (), with trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two H-3-bpmp ligands and trans sip carboxylate oxygen atom donors. Deviations from idealized square pyramidal geometry are different at Cu1 and Cu2, with Addison τ trigonality factors equal to 0.173 and 0.127, respectively. The long bond length apical positions at all copper ions are taken up by aqua ligands. Pertinent bond lengths and angles about copper are consistent with the coordination environment and d 9 Jahn-Teller active electronic configuration and are given in .

elements.content: Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are linked by sip ligands in a bis(monodentate) μ2-κO:O′ bridging mode (Scheme ) to form [Cu(sip)(H2O)] n n− zigzag polymeric chains that are oriented along the [1 0 0] crystal direction. The Cu···Cu contact distances through the crystallographically distinct sip ligands are 9.505 and 9.543 Å; the next nearest neighbor Cu···Cu distance along the chains defines the a lattice parameter. Adjacent [Cu(sip)(H2O)] n n− chains are connected into neutral coordination polymer (4,4) layered grids orientated along the ac crystal planes by protonated tethering H3-bpmp ligands (Figure ). The Cu···Cu contact distances through the kinked dipyridyl tethers measure 9.525 and 9.528 Å. Conformations of bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands can be evaluated through the angle (κ) between the pyridyl nitrogen termini and the piperazinyl ring centroid. Respective κ angles for the crystallographically distinct H-3-bpmp ligands are 123.6 and 115.9°. Through-space Cu···Cu distances across the grid apertures measure ∼12.4 × ∼14.4 Å, with Cu···Cu···Cu angles around the grid perimeters subtending ∼81 and ∼98°. The pendant sulfonate groups of the sip ligands project toward the interior of the coordination polymer grid windows.

elements.content: [Cu(sip)(H-3-bpmp)(H2O)] n layers stack in an offset ABAB pattern, with interlayer interdigitation of H-3-bpmp ligands (). Disordered water molecules of crystallization occupy cavities within and between the layer motifs, anchored to the coordination polymer matrix by hydrogen bonding mechanisms involving unligated carboxylate and sulfonate oxygen atoms of the sip ligands and protonated piperazinyl rings of the H3-bpmp ligands. According to PLATON, the solvent accessible regions of 1 comprise 11.7% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in an acentric orthorhombic space group with an asymmetric unit containing a divalent copper ion, an sip ligand, one aqua ligand, one 4-bpmp ligand protonated at one of its piperazinyl nitrogen atoms, and four total water molecules of crystallization. The copper ion is coordinated in a highly distorted {CuN2O3} square pyramidal coordination environment (τ = 0.433), with trans sip carboxylate oxygen atom donors and trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms belonging to two different H4-bpmp ligands (). Aqua ligands occupy the apical sites. Relevant bond lengths and angles about copper are consistent with the d9 electronic configuration ().

Compound 2 crystallizes in an acentric orthorhombic space group with an asymmetric unit containing a divalent copper ion, an sip ligand, one aqua ligand, one 4-bpmp ligand protonated at one of its piperazinyl nitrogen atoms, and four total water molecules of crystallization. The copper ion is coordinated in a highly distorted {CuN2O3} square pyramidal coordination environment (τ = 0.433), with trans sip carboxylate oxygen atom donors and trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms belonging to two different H4-bpmp ligands (). Aqua ligands occupy the apical sites. Relevant bond lengths and angles about copper are consistent with the d9 electronic configuration ().

elements.content: As in 1, divalent copper atoms in 2 are connected by sip ligands in a bis(monodentate) bridging mode, constructing [Cu(sip)(H2O)] n n− polymeric chains. However, the pendant sulfonate functional groups point in the same direction, unlike in the alternating fashion seen in 1 and thereby promoting the acentricity of 2. The Cu···Cu contact distance through the sip ligands is 10.834 Å, delineating the a lattice parameter. [Cu(sip)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)] n neutral (4,4) coordination polymer grids (Figure ) are formed in 2, by the linkage of [Cu(sip)(H2O)] n n− chains through H4-bpmp ligands whose κ angles measure 178°. The more obtuse κ angle results in a substantial longer through-ligand Cu···Cu distance (16.476 Å) than seen in 1. As a result, the grid apertures are significantly larger in 2, with through-space Cu···Cu distances measuring 21.178 × 18.142 Å.

elements.content: The larger apertures in 2 permit 2D + 2D → 3D mutually inclined interpenetration of two parallel sets of [Cu(sip)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)] n layers (Figure ), in marked contrast to the offset parallel stacking of similar layers in the 3-bpmp analogue 1. The angle of interpenetration of the layers is 83.3° as determined by TOPOS software. Stabilization of the mutually interpenetrated layer structure is provided by hydrogen-bonding interactions between protonated piperazinyl nitrogen atoms in the H4-bpmp ligands and unligated sulfonate groups, and between aqua ligands and unprotonated piperazinyl nitrogen atoms in the H4-bpmp ligands. Small box-shaped channels coursing between interpenetrated, bracketed by aqua ligands and piperazinyl rings, contain isolated water molecules of crystallization and water molecule dimers. These channels comprise 13.4% of the unit cell volume.

The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains a divalent copper ion, an sip ligand, one 4-bpmp ligand protonated at one of its piperazinyl nitrogen atoms, and eight water molecules of crystallization, one of which lies on a crystallographic 2-fold rotation axis (). The copper ion is coordinated in an extremely distorted {CuN2O3} square pyramidal coordination environment (τ = 0.487). Its basal plane is occupied by trans carboxylate oxygen atom donors from two sip ligands, and trans pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two H4-bpmp ligands; the apical site contains a carboxylate oxygen atom from a third sip ligand. Bond lengths and angles about copper are listed in .

elements.content: The lack of aqua ligands in 3 allows the sip ligands to adopt an exotridentate μ3-κO:O′:O′′ bridging mode (Scheme ), which link copper ions into anionic [Cu(sip)] n n− chains with embedded {Cu2(OCO)2} dimeric kernels (Figure ). Within the dimers the pair of carboxylate groups bridge apical and basal coordination sites. The through-space Cu···Cu and C···C distances across a single {Cu2(OCO)2} dimer are 4.155 and 4.667 Å, respectively. Similar chain motifs have been seen in the isophthalate-containing phases [Cu(isophthalate)(4,4′-dipyridylamine)] n and [Cu(isophthalate)(4,4′-bpy)] n .

elements.content: Each {Cu2(OCO)2} dimer is connected to four neighboring dimers by tethering H4-bpmp ligands, which rest in a slightly more curled conformation than those in 2 (κ = 171.4°). Through the dipodal H4-bpmp tethering ligands [Cu(sip)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)] n layers are constructed, which are oriented parallel to the (1 0 1̅) crystal planes (Figure ). The Cu···Cu through-ligand distance is 16.420 Å, slightly shorter than in 2 because of the more curled H4-bpmp conformation. As each {Cu2(OCO)2} dimer is connected to six others, the 2-D net of 3 can be considered a relatively uncommon (3,6) triangular regular net. The smaller apertures within the triangular grids prevent the mutually inclined interpenetration seen in 2, and promote an offset ABAB layer stacking pattern () more closely resembling that observed in 1. Water molecule tapes (Figure ) composed of cyclic tetramers linked by discrete decorated water molecule chains are situated within the interlayer regions, which occupy 30.7% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: A lower temperature pseudopolymorph of 2 and 3, compound 4 contains an asymmetric unit consisting of 3 crystallographically distinct divalent copper ions, 3 sip trianions, 1-1/2 4-bpmp molecules whose piperazinyl nitrogen atoms are fully protonated, 10 aqua ligands, and 2 net water molecules of crystallization. Two of the copper ions (Cu1 and Cu3) manifest a Jahn−Teller distorted {CuO5N}octahedral coordination environment, while Cu2 possesses a {CuO4N} square planar coordination geometry (τ = 0.13). The coordination environment at Cu1 contains three mer-disposed aqua ligands, an H24-bpmp pyridyl nitrogen donor, and carboxylate oxygen and sulfonate oxygen donors from two different sip ligands oriented in a cis fashion; the longer axial sites are taken up by an aqua ligand and an sip sulfonate oxygen donor. At Cu2, aqua ligands occupy the apical site and two trans basal positions, with an H24-bpmp pyridyl nitrogen donor and a sip carboxylate oxygen atom also resting in trans basal positions. A pyridyl nitrogen donor from an H24-bpmp ligand and an sip carboxylate oxygen in trans positions, along with a pair of trans aqua ligands denote the equatorial plane of the coordination sphere at Cu3, with aqua ligands also in the longer axial positions. Bond lengths and angles within the coordination spheres in 4 are listed in .

A lower temperature pseudopolymorph of 2 and 3, compound 4 contains an asymmetric unit consisting of 3 crystallographically distinct divalent copper ions, 3 sip trianions, 1-1/2 4-bpmp molecules whose piperazinyl nitrogen atoms are fully protonated, 10 aqua ligands, and 2 net water molecules of crystallization. Two of the copper ions (Cu1 and Cu3) manifest a Jahn-Teller distorted {CuO5N}octahedral coordination environment, while Cu2 possesses a {CuO4N} square planar coordination geometry (τ = 0.13). The coordination environment at Cu1 contains three mer-disposed aqua ligands, an H24-bpmp pyridyl nitrogen donor, and carboxylate oxygen and sulfonate oxygen donors from two different sip ligands oriented in a cis fashion; the longer axial sites are taken up by an aqua ligand and an sip sulfonate oxygen donor. At Cu2, aqua ligands occupy the apical site and two trans basal positions, with an H24-bpmp pyridyl nitrogen donor and a sip carboxylate oxygen atom also resting in trans basal positions. A pyridyl nitrogen donor from an H24-bpmp ligand and an sip carboxylate oxygen in trans positions, along with a pair of trans aqua ligands denote the equatorial plane of the coordination sphere at Cu3, with aqua ligands also in the longer axial positions. Bond lengths and angles within the coordination spheres in 4 are listed in .

elements.content: A hexanuclear [Cu6(sip)6(H24-bpmp)3(H2O)20] oligomeric molecular structure is observed for 4 (Figure ), formed by the bridging of isolated copper ions by sip and H24-bpmp ligands. Cu3 and Cu2 atoms are bridged by H24-bpmp ligands with a splayed-open conformation (κ = 176.1°); these span Cu···Cu distances of 16.451 Å. Cu2 and Cu1 atoms are connected by exobidentate sip ligands, bridged through one monodentate carboxylate and one monodentate sulfonate oygen atom (μ2-κO:O′ binding mode, Scheme ). The Cu2···Cu1 distance measures 9.866 Å. A pair of Cu1 atoms at the center of the oligomer is bridged by a H24-bpmp ligand situated across a crystallographic inversion center, at a distance of 16.451 Å. Monodentate sip ligands bound via carboxylate groups at Cu3 atoms lay on the periphery of the oligomeric molecule, preventing further covalent aggregation. Intramolecular π−π stacking between the aromatic rings of the sip ligands (centroid-to-centroid distance = 3.773 Å) serves to stabilize the oligomeric structure. The approximate distance from one tip of the oligomer to the other is ∼86 Å.

elements.content: The large asymmetric unit of compound 5 contains four divalent copper ions, two fully deprotonated sip trianions, two hydroxide ions, three aqua ligands, one ligated 4-bpfp molecule, and one water molecule of crystallization (). Copper atoms Cu1 and Cu3 exhibit distorted square pyramidal {CuO5} coordination environments, with cis hydroxide ions and cis sip carboxylate oxygen atoms occupying their basal planes, and aqua ligands found in the apical sites. Distortion from idealized square pyramidal geometry differs at Cu1 and Cu3, with τ trigonality factors of 0.272 and 0.210, respectively. Cu2 also possesses a much more regular square pyramidal environment (τ = 0.011) but with a {CuO4N} arrangement. Here, the basal plane is filled by trans disposed sip carboxylate oxygen atoms, a hydroxide ion, and a pyridyl nitrogen donor atom from a 4-bpfp ligand, while the apical site contains a bound water molecule. Cu4 is octahedrally coordinated in a {CuO5N} pattern. The equatorial plane of the Jahn−Teller distorted octahedron contains trans carboxylate donor atoms from two sip ligands, a hydroxide ion, and a pyridyl nitrogen donor atom from a 4-bpfp ligand. A formyl oxygen atom donor from another 4-bpfp ligand and a sulfonate oxygen atom from another sip ligand are located in the long apical positions. The μ3-bridging hydroxide ions and μ2-κO:O′ sip carboxylate groups form {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} “butterfly” tetranuclear clusters (Figure ). Embedded within the center of the clusters are {Cu2(OH)2} rhomboid dimers in which hydroxide ligands bridge Cu1 and Cu3 atoms in an equatorial−equatorial fashion. The Cu···Cu and O···O contact distances within the {Cu2(OH)2} units are 3.015 and 2.599 Å, respectively. The hydroxide ligands engage in corner-sharing among three copper coordination environments to provide the connectivity to form the “butterfly” clusters. Additionally, the central rhomboid dimers connect to the Cu2 and Cu4 atoms situated on the periphery of the clusters via four carboxylate groups from the sip ligands, all bridging copper atoms in an equatorial−equatorial manner. The Cu···Cu contact distances between the central and peripheral copper atoms within the cluster range from 3.42 to 3.53 Å. Bond lengths and angles within the cluster are given in .

Structural Description of {[Cu4(sip)2(OH)2(H2O)3(4-bpfp)]⋅H2O} n  (5)

The large asymmetric unit of compound 5 contains four divalent copper ions, two fully deprotonated sip trianions, two hydroxide ions, three aqua ligands, one ligated 4-bpfp molecule, and one water molecule of crystallization (). Copper atoms Cu1 and Cu3 exhibit distorted square pyramidal {CuO5} coordination environments, with cis hydroxide ions and cis sip carboxylate oxygen atoms occupying their basal planes, and aqua ligands found in the apical sites. Distortion from idealized square pyramidal geometry differs at Cu1 and Cu3, with τ trigonality factors of 0.272 and 0.210, respectively. Cu2 also possesses a much more regular square pyramidal environment (τ = 0.011) but with a {CuO4N} arrangement. Here, the basal plane is filled by trans disposed sip carboxylate oxygen atoms, a hydroxide ion, and a pyridyl nitrogen donor atom from a 4-bpfp ligand, while the apical site contains a bound water molecule. Cu4 is octahedrally coordinated in a {CuO5N} pattern. The equatorial plane of the Jahn-Teller distorted octahedron contains trans carboxylate donor atoms from two sip ligands, a hydroxide ion, and a pyridyl nitrogen donor atom from a 4-bpfp ligand. A formyl oxygen atom donor from another 4-bpfp ligand and a sulfonate oxygen atom from another sip ligand are located in the long apical positions. The μ3-bridging hydroxide ions and μ2-κO:O' sip carboxylate groups form {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} "butterfly" tetranuclear clusters (Figure ). Embedded within the center of the clusters are {Cu2(OH)2} rhomboid dimers in which hydroxide ligands bridge Cu1 and Cu3 atoms in an equatorial-equatorial fashion. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu and O⋅⋅⋅O contact distances within the {Cu2(OH)2} units are 3.015 and 2.599 Å, respectively. The hydroxide ligands engage in corner-sharing among three copper coordination environments to provide the connectivity to form the "butterfly" clusters. Additionally, the central rhomboid dimers connect to the Cu2 and Cu4 atoms situated on the periphery of the clusters via four carboxylate groups from the sip ligands, all bridging copper atoms in an equatorial-equatorial manner. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu contact distances between the central and peripheral copper atoms within the cluster range from 3.42 to 3.53 Å. Bond lengths and angles within the cluster are given in .

elements.content: The tetranuclear clusters are connected into neutral 1-D [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2] n ribbons (Figure ) through two sets of sip ligands (Scheme ). One type of sip ligand (sip-A) has an exotetradentate μ4-κ4 O:O′:O′′:O′′′ binding mode that links a pair of clusters along the periphery of the ribbon motif through both of its carboxylate end groups. The other type of sip ligand (sip-B) has an exopentadentate μ5-κ5 O:O′:O′′:O′′′:O′′′′ binding mode that links three individual tetranuclear clusters in the interior of the ribbon, by ligating through both of its carboxylate groups and also its sulfonate pendant arm. Individual [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2] n ribbons are connected into a [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2(4-bpfp)] n slab-like layer through the pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms of the 4-bpfp ligands. The 4-bpfp ligands bridge Cu2 and Cu4 atoms on the edges of {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} tetranuclear clusters located in different [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2] n ribbon motifs, with a Cu···Cu contact distance of 16.241 Å.

elements.content: In turn, the [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2(4-bpfp)] n slabs are covalently linked into a non-interpenetrated 3-D coordination polymer network via 4-bpfp formyl oxygen atoms (Figure ), which bind to Cu4 atoms in neighboring slabs. In order to simplify this network, the {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} tetranuclear clusters, sip-B ligands, and 4-bpfp ligands can be considered as connecting nodes, while the cluster-bridging sip-A ligands are treated as simple linkers. Within the [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2] n ribbon motifs, the sip-B ligands bridge three separate tetranuclear clusters and thus are 3-connected nodes. Each 4-bpfp ligand acts as a 3-connected node, joining together two clusters within a [Cu4(OH)2(sip)2(4-bpfp)] n slabs (via pyridyl donors) and binding to one other cluster in a neighboring slab (via a formyl donor). The {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} tetranuclear clusters themselves serve as 8-connected nodes, linking to three sip-B 3-connected nodes, joining to two other clusters directly through sip-A rods and making connections to three 4-bpfp nodes (two via pyridyl donors and one via a formyl donor). Investigation of the resulting network (Figure ) with TOPOS software reveals a unique three-dimensional (3-D) 3,3,8-connected trinodal topology with (3.42)(426)(3244536977829) topology. Isolated water molecules occupy the small residual solvent-accessible space (1.3% of the unit cell volume).

elements.content: Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out to investigate spin communication within the axial−equatorial bridged {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers in 3 and within the {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} “butterfly” tetranuclear clusters in 5. For 3, the χm T product of 0.42 cm3-K mol Cu1− at 300 K corresponds roughly to that expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 Cu2+ ion. A slow decrease in χm T product value occurs between 300 and 50 K, below which temperature it decreases rapidly, reaching 0.08 cm3-K mol−1 at 2 K. The data were fit (Figure ) to the Bleaney−Bowers expression for an interacting pair of S = 1/2 ions (eq ), giving g = 2.148(3) and J = −4.63(6) cm−1 with R = {Σ[(χm T)obs − (χm T)calc]2}1/2 = 1.16 × 10−4. The variable temperature behavior and small negative exchange integral value are both consistent with weak antiferromagnetic carboxylate-mediated superexchange between divalent copper ions in the {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers in 3. The significant deviations from idealized square pyramidal coordination environment permit some level of d x 2 −y 2 magnetic orbital overlap despite the axial−equatorial carboxylate bridging mode, which would force orthogonality of d x 2 −y2 orbitals in a pair of perfect square pyramidal environments. χ m T = ( N g 2 β 2 3 k ) [ 1 + { 1 3 exp ( J / k T ) } ] − 1

Magnetic Properties of 3 and 5 

Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out to investigate spin communication within the axial-equatorial bridged {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers in 3 and within the {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} "butterfly" tetranuclear clusters in 5. For 3, the χm T product of 0.42 cm3-K mol Cu1- at 300 K corresponds roughly to that expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 Cu2+ ion. A slow decrease in χm T product value occurs between 300 and 50 K, below which temperature it decreases rapidly, reaching 0.08 cm3-K mol-1 at 2 K. The data were fit (Figure ) to the Bleaney-Bowers expression for an interacting pair of S = 1/2 ions (eq ), giving g = 2.148(3) and J = -4.63(6) cm-1 with R = {Σ[(χm T)obs - (χm T)calc]2}1/2 = 1.16 × 10-4. The variable temperature behavior and small negative exchange integral value are both consistent with weak antiferromagnetic carboxylate-mediated superexchange between divalent copper ions in the {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers in 3. The significant deviations from idealized square pyramidal coordination environment permit some level of d  x   2  -y  2  magnetic orbital overlap despite the axial-equatorial carboxylate bridging mode, which would force orthogonality of d  x   2  -y2  orbitals in a pair of perfect square pyramidal environments. 1    χ   m   T =  (    N   g   2     β   2     3 k    )     [  1 +  {    1   3    exp  (  J / k T  )   }   ]    - 1

elements.content: For 5, the χm T product of 0.41 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 300 K corresponds roughly to that expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 Cu2+ ion. Decrease in χm T product upon cooling to 2 K is indicative of antiferromagnetic coupling within the tetrameric clusters. The magnetic susceptibility data for 5 were fit to an equation used by Xu (eq ) for modeling the magnetic behavior of {[Cu4(OH)2(sip)2(H2O)2]·4H2O} n , which possesses similar tetranuclear clusters to those in 5. In this model, J 1 and J 2 define the exchange integral between copper ions situated on opposite and adjacent sides of the rectangular tetramer, respectively. In 5, Cu1 and Cu3 atoms on opposite sides of the tetrameric {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} cluster form equatorial−equatorial bridged {Cu2(OH)2} dimers, while Cu2 and Cu4 atoms on opposite sides of the cluster are not directly bridged. Thus, the J 1 term is used to indicate magnetic interaction between Cu1 and Cu3 only. All copper ions within the cluster are also connected to two adjacent neighbors via equatorial−equatorial carboxylate and hydroxide bridging ligands; these magnetic interactions are described by J 2. Via this approach, the best-fit values to eq (Figure ) obtained were g = 2.31(1), J 1 = −19(1) cm−1, and J 2 = −29(2) cm−1 with R = 2.6 × 10−4, corroborating the presence of mutual antiferromagnetic coupling pathways within the tetranuclear clusters in 5. χ m = ( N g 2 β 2 12 k T ) ( A B ) A = 30 exp ( 2 J 1 / k T + 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + 6 exp ( − 2 J 1 / k T + 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + 6 exp ( 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + 6 exp ( − 1.5 J 2 / k T ) B = 5 exp ( 2 J 1 / k T + 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + 3 exp ( − 2 J 1 / k T + 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + exp ( − 4 J 1 / k T + 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + 3 exp ( 0.5 J 2 / k T ) + 4 exp ( − 1.5 J 2 / k T )

elements.content: Bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands with protonated piperazinyl rings have provided the appropriate charge balance necessary to instill higher dimensionalities in copper sulfoisophthalate coordination polymers with a 1:1 metal/sulfoisophthalate stoichiometric ratio, in contrast to the 1-D ribbons seen in previous complexes with 4,4′-bipyridine. The nitrogen donor disposition within the bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands (3-bpmp vs 4-bpmp) and the presence of aqua ligands appears to affect the supramolecular interaction of (4,4) grid layers, from parallel stacking to mutual inclined interpenetration. A low temperature 4-bpmp-containing pseudopolymorph with a plethora of aqua ligands displayed a long hexanuclear oligomeric structure, reducing dimensionality to a 0-D molecular species. Using the similar bis(pyridylformyl)piperazine co-ligand, 4-bpfp which lacks the facility for piperazinyl ring protonation, resulted in the generation of hydroxide- and carboxylate-bridged tetranuclear copper clusters, a feature seen in other copper sulfoisophthalate coordination polymers. The ability of the formyl group in 4-bpfp to act as a weak axial ligand for divalent copper afforded a novel 3-D net and portends a rich coordination polymer chemistry for this underutilized ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands with protonated piperazinyl rings have provided the appropriate charge balance necessary to instill higher dimensionalities in copper sulfoisophthalate coordination polymers with a 1:1 metal/sulfoisophthalate stoichiometric ratio, in contrast to the 1-D ribbons seen in previous complexes with 4,4'-bipyridine. The nitrogen donor disposition within the bis(pyridylmethyl)piperazine ligands (3-bpmp vs 4-bpmp) and the presence of aqua ligands appears to affect the supramolecular interaction of (4,4) grid layers, from parallel stacking to mutual inclined interpenetration. A low temperature 4-bpmp-containing pseudopolymorph with a plethora of aqua ligands displayed a long hexanuclear oligomeric structure, reducing dimensionality to a 0-D molecular species. Using the similar bis(pyridylformyl)piperazine co-ligand, 4-bpfp which lacks the facility for piperazinyl ring protonation, resulted in the generation of hydroxide- and carboxylate-bridged tetranuclear copper clusters, a feature seen in other copper sulfoisophthalate coordination polymers. The ability of the formyl group in 4-bpfp to act as a weak axial ligand for divalent copper afforded a novel 3-D net and portends a rich coordination polymer chemistry for this underutilized ligand.

cln_elements.content:
[Cu(sip)(H-3-bpmp)(H2O)] n layers stack in an offset ABAB pattern, with interlayer interdigitation of H-3-bpmp ligands (). Disordered water molecules of crystallization occupy cavities within and between the layer motifs, anchored to the coordination polymer matrix by hydrogen bonding mechanisms involving unligated carboxylate and sulfonate oxygen atoms of the sip ligands and protonated piperazinyl rings of the H3-bpmp ligands. According to PLATON, the solvent accessible regions of 1 comprise 11.7% of the unit cell volume.

Magnetic Properties of <bold>3</bold> and <bold>5</bold>

Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out to investigate spin communication within the axial−equatorial bridged {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers in 3 and within the {Cu4(OH)2(OCO)4} “butterfly” tetranuclear clusters in 5. For 3, the χm T product of 0.42 cm3-K mol Cu1− at 300 K corresponds roughly to that expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 Cu2+ ion. A slow decrease in χm T product value occurs between 300 and 50 K, below which temperature it decreases rapidly, reaching 0.08 cm3-K mol−1 at 2 K. The data were fit (Figure ) to the Bleaney−Bowers expression for an interacting pair of S = 1/2 ions (eq ), giving g = 2.148(3) and J = −4.63(6) cm−1 with R = {Σ[(χm T)obs − (χm T)calc]2}1/2 = 1.16 × 10−4. The variable temperature behavior and small negative exchange integral value are both consistent with weak antiferromagnetic carboxylate-mediated superexchange between divalent copper ions in the {Cu2(OCO)2} dimers in 3. The significant deviations from idealized square pyramidal coordination environment permit some level of d x 2 −y 2 magnetic orbital overlap despite the axial−equatorial carboxylate bridging mode, which would force orthogonality of d x 2 −y2 orbitals in a pair of perfect square pyramidal environments. χ m T = ( N g 2 β 2 3 k ) [ 1 + { 1 3 exp ( J / k T ) } ] − 1
